questions.question: What is the most abundant class of plasma protein?
questions.rationale: Albumin (~60% of total plasma protein at a concentration of about 4 g/dl) is the most abundant plasma protein.

questions.question: What is the effect of low plasma albumin?
options: Clotting factors decrease, thus increasing chance of prolonged bleeding.
Fewer immunoglobulins synthesized, impairing immune function.
Less iron stored, increasing iron deficiency anemia.
Osmotic pressure decreases, water moves into interstitium.
questions.rationale: Low albumin decreases oncotic pressure → fluid moves into tissues → decreased blood volume.

questions.question: What is the life span of an erythrocyte (in days)?
questions.rationale: Because erythrocytes cannot undergo mitosis, life span is ~120 days.

questions.question: Which statement concerning erythrocytes is true?
options: Erythrocytes contain a nucleus, mitochondria, and ribosomes.
Erythrocytes deform to squeeze through capillaries.
questions.rationale: Reversible deformity enables erythrocytes to assume torpedo-like shape and squeeze through circulation.

questions.question: Granulocytes that contain vasoactive amines such as histamine are called:
questions.rationale: Basophils contain histamine, chemotactic factors, enzymes, and heparin.

questions.question: Which blood elements are disk-shaped cytoplasmic fragments essential for clotting?
questions.rationale: Platelets are cytoplasmic fragments essential for clotting.

questions.question: Blood cells that differentiate into macrophages are known as:
questions.rationale: Only monocytes migrate and become macrophages.

questions.question: Without prior exposure to antigen, which cells destroy some tumor and virus-infected cells?
questions.rationale: Natural killer cells kill some tumor/virus-infected cells without prior exposure.

questions.question: What is the life span of platelets (in days)?
questions.rationale: Platelets circulate ~10 days.

questions.question: Fetal hematopoiesis occurs in which structure?
questions.rationale: Spleen is the largest secondary hematopoietic organ in fetus.

questions.question: What is the consequence of splenectomy?
questions.rationale: Splenectomy results in defective cells remaining in circulation.

questions.question: During infection, why do lymph nodes enlarge?
questions.rationale: B-lymphocyte proliferation causes lymph node enlargement.

questions.question: Which blood cells are the chief phagocytes of early inflammation?
questions.rationale: Neutrophils are the chief phagocytes of early inflammation.

questions.question: Which blood cells are biconcave in shape and deformable?
questions.rationale: Erythrocytes are biconcave and deformable, aiding gas transport.

questions.question: Which hemoglobin is made from oxidized ferric iron (Fe3+) and cannot bind oxygen?
questions.rationale: Methemoglobin (Fe3+) cannot bind oxygen.

questions.question: Absence of parietal cells would prevent absorption of which nutrient?
questions.rationale: Without parietal cells, intrinsic factor (IF) cannot transport vitamin B12 → pernicious anemia.

questions.question: Which nutrients are necessary for DNA synthesis and erythrocyte maturation?
questions.rationale: Cobalamin and folate are essential for DNA synthesis.

questions.question: Which nutrients are necessary for hemoglobin synthesis?
questions.rationale: Iron and B6 are essential for hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.question: Recycling of iron from erythrocytes is made possible by which?
questions.rationale: Transferrin recycles iron by binding and transporting it.

questions.question: By which structure are mature erythrocytes removed from the bloodstream?
questions.rationale: After ~100–120 days, old erythrocytes are removed by macrophages, primarily in the spleen.

questions.question: Which substance is used to correct the chronic anemia associated with chronic renal failure?
questions.rationale: Erythropoietin is used in treatment of chronic anemia of renal failure.

questions.question: What is the role of thromboxane A2 (TXA2) in hemostasis?
questions.rationale: TXA2 stimulates platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.

questions.question: Which of the following is the role of nitric oxide (NO) in hemostasis?
options: Controls platelet activation through cGMP-mediated signaling
questions.rationale: NO controls platelet activation through cyclic GMP signaling.

questions.question: The drug heparin acts in hemostasis by which processes?
options: Preventing conversion of prothrombin to thrombin
questions.rationale: Heparin enhances antithrombin III activity.

questions.question: What is plasmin’s role in the clotting process?
questions.rationale: Plasmin degrades fibrin polymers in clots.

questions.question: What does polycythemia at birth indicate?
questions.rationale: Polycythemia indicates hypoxia in utero.

questions.question: Where are Kupffer cells located?
questions.rationale: Kupffer cells are macrophages in the liver.

questions.question: Where are Langerhans cells found?
questions.rationale: Langerhans cells are found in skin.

questions.question: What is the role of collagen in clotting?
questions.rationale: Collagen provides strong stimulus to activate platelets.

questions.question: Which form of iron can be used in hemoglobin?
questions.rationale: Only reduced ferrous iron (Fe2+) can bind oxygen.

questions.question: Where are alveolar macrophages found?
questions.rationale: Alveolar macrophages are found in lungs.

questions.question: What changes to the hematologic system are related to aging?
questions.rationale: Lymphocyte function decreases with age.

questions.question: What is the function of erythrocytes?
questions.rationale: Erythrocytes are solely responsible for oxygenation.

questions.question: Which characteristics allow erythrocytes to function as gas carriers? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Erythrocytes are biconcave and deformable.

questions.question: Which statements about plasma proteins are correct? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Plasma proteins do not create hydrostatic pressure.

questions.question: What are the primary anticoagulant mechanisms? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Major anticoagulants include antithrombin III, tissue factor inhibitors, protein C.

questions.question: Which statements are true regarding the role of endothelium in clot formation? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Endothelium resists clot formation with protease inhibitors, thrombomodulin, protein C.

questions.question: Which statements characterize albumin? (Select all that apply.)
questions.rationale: Albumin maintains osmotic pressure, is synthesized in liver, and carries water-insoluble drugs.

questions.question: Matching: Endomitosis, Hemostasis, Hematopoiesis, Erythropoiesis, Phagocytosis
questions.rationale: 39. Endomitosis → Platelet formation; 40. Hemostasis → Clotting; 41. Hematopoiesis → Blood cell production; 42. Erythropoiesis → Red blood cell development; 43. Phagocytosis → Red blood cell destruction.
